awd_titl_txt: CyberTraining: CIC: The Texas A&M University Computational Materials Science Summer School (CMS3)
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in both hardware and software infrastructure are quickly making it possible to carry out realistic simulations of materials and materials phenomena that can lead to a better understanding of their behavior. Simulations constitute one of the key ingredients necessary to realize the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI), which calls for the reduction in time and resources necessary to develop the materials needed to enable potentially transformative technologies. To push the thriving field of Computational Materials Science (CMS) forward it is necessary to provide the next generation research workforce with a broad exposure to as many computational techniques as possible.  This project brings together researchers in materials science and engineering, and in advanced cyber-infrastructure (CI) to establish the Computational Materials Science Summer School (CMS3) that aims to train graduate students and junior scientists and engineers in some of the most advanced and widely used computational materials science simulation tools. The training provided by CMS3 will equip participating students with the knowledge and skills necessary to push the frontiers of simulation-enabled materials research. Furthermore, CMS3 will contribute to MGI's mission of maintaining the Nation's overall economic competitiveness and security by training the scientists and engineers that will discover and develop the materials that will make technologies of national importance possible.

This award leverages existing cyber-infrastructure to expand participation, including from underrepresented groups, through local and remote training. Expert instructors are selected from academic, domestic and international institutions, and national laboratories to cover three modules: continuum micromechanics, mesoscopic simulation and atomistic modeling, along with an overarching theme of data science. The school targets 20 on-site and up to 80 remote graduate and post-doctoral researchers, including industry participants. The activities of CMS3 are to (i) establish a CMS network among national laboratories and academic institutions to leverage the expertise of the CMS community at large in developing the next-generation workforce in materials research across multiple scales; (ii) develop a CMS curriculum, commensurate with a summer school format, that involves utilizing and supporting advanced CI for effective scale-up of a series of practica; (iii) organize shorter seed programs in specialized areas, such as dislocation dynamics, phase-field modeling and data-enabled materials science; (iv) integrate the theoretical foundations and practical training into the graduate curriculum and continuing education at Texas A&M University and elsewhere; and (v) introduce immersive visualization through virtual and augmented reality tools to help students with different backgrounds and learning styles interpret complex material data. Course material and software codes associated with this project not already disseminated by the original developers are maintained in a GitHub repository. This ensures that all released materials and packages are preserved to maintain historical context and broad access.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the rapidly evolving field of Computational Materials Science (CMS), the NSF-funded Computational Materials Science Summer School (CMS3) has been a beacon of innovation and education. The project's intellectual merit is deeply rooted in its comprehensive approach to training—a curriculum that stretches from the electronic structure to the continuum of materials. The broader impacts are evident in the school's commitment to inclusivity and the democratization of knowledge, reaching a diverse group of students and junior scientists from around the globe.

From its inception, CMS3 has been dedicated to equipping the next generation with the robust knowledge and skills required to push the frontiers of simulation-enabled materials research. This is not just a summer school but a transformative experience that has, over the years, become the reference in its field. The training modules, designed and delivered by the very creators of the computational tools, provide an unmatched authenticity and depth of understanding to the participants.

Throughout the life of the award, CMS3 has consistently hosted 40-50 students annually, with numbers swelling to 70 in recent years. The school has welcomed a third of its attendees from Texas A&M University, with the rest comprising both national and international students and professionals. Maintaining a 25% participation rate of female students, the school has made strides in representing gender diversity within the CMS field.

The school's intellectual merit shone brightly as it navigated the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic, swiftly transitioning to a fully virtual format in 2020 and 2021 and subsequently adopting a hybrid model in 2022. The continuity and quality of education remained unwavering, demonstrating the program's resilience and adaptability—an essential trait for the future of scientific education.

Feedback from participants has been overwhelmingly positive. The quality of the CMS3 program was highly rated, with the practical exercises and instructor quality receiving exceptional praise. A full 100% of participants would recommend the school to their peers—a testament to the program's impact on their academic and professional pursuits.

As we look to the future, the school is poised for expansion with a fresh NSF Cyber-Training grant, aimed at integrating AI/ML techniques into materials science. This cutting-edge addition ensures that CMS3 stays at the forefront of educational advancements, further solidifying its role in shaping a skilled workforce capable of leading transformative technologies.

The broader impact of CMS3 extends beyond immediate educational outcomes. It has been institutionalized as a part of the regular curriculum at Texas A&M University, influencing materials science education at a foundational level. By fostering a network of knowledge that connects students and experts across various institutions and countries, CMS3 contributes to the nation's economic competitiveness.

In conclusion, the CMS3 is more than a summer school—it is a nexus of education, innovation, and community in the computational materials science landscape. Its enduring legacy is not just in the advanced curriculum it offers but in the collaborative networks it strengthens, the careers it shapes, and the scientific frontiers it helps to expand.
